title: CSS Class Reference
text: Quick reference for all user-facing CSS classes. Both themes (Academic and UNM) share these classes.

title: CSS Class Reference
text:
Slide Types
Apply as a class on any slide heading: ## Title {.small-slide}



Class
Effect




.small-slide
Reduced font size for dense content


.tiny-slide
Even smaller for reference tables


.quote-slide
Centered text with styled blockquote


.image-slide
Minimal chrome, image-focused


.section-slide
Large centered heading for section dividers


.slide-code
Optimized for code-heavy slides


.large-image-slide
Full-height image display (80vh max)


.scrollable
Enable vertical scrolling on a slide

title: CSS Class Reference
text:
Emphasis Spans
Inline markup: [text]{.alert}



Class
Effect




.alert
Bold, alert color, tinted background


.fg
Bold, accent foreground color


.bg
White text on accent background


.highlight
Yellow/gold highlighted text


.note
Italic, tinted background


.warning
Bold, warning color, tinted background

title: CSS Class Reference
text:
Font Sizing
Apply to a slide or a div to scale all content inside:



Class
Text
Code blocks scale too




.larger
1.50em
Yes


.largest
1.20em
Yes


.large
1.25em
Yes


.small
0.80em
Yes


.smaller
0.64em
Yes


.smallest
0.51em
Yes

title: CSS Class Reference
text:
Alignment

Text (horizontal)



Class
Effect




.left
Left-aligned


.center
Centered


.right
Right-aligned





Vertical (grid-based)



Class
Effect




.v-center
Centered


.v-top
Top


.v-bottom
Bottom

title: CSS Class Reference
text:
Buttons and Badges
[[Jump to Slide]{.button}](#target-id)

Inline labels: [v1.1.0]{.badge} [New]{.badge-secondary}



Class
Effect




.button
Accent-colored link button with icon


.badge
Primary-colored inline label


.badge-primary
Same as .badge


.badge-secondary
Lighter variant

title: CSS Class Reference
text:
Custom Callouts
::: {.callout-example}
Worked example content.
:::



Class
Title
Border color




.callout-example
Example
Green (success)


.callout-question
Question
Primary (navy/cherry)


.callout-insight
Insight
Blue (info/turquoise)



Standard Quarto callouts (.callout-note, .callout-warning, .callout-tip, .callout-important, .callout-caution) are also styled.

title: CSS Class Reference
text:
Code Blocks
No classes needed. Applied automatically:

Source code blocks use Fira Code font with syntax highlighting
R console output gets a lighter background with an accent-colored left border
Use output-location: column in chunk options for side-by-side layout

title: CSS Class Reference
text:
Tables
No classes needed. Applied automatically:

Striped alternating rows
Uppercase header text
No hover effect (keeps presentations clean)

title: CSS Class Reference
text:
Citations & References
Add bibliography: refs.bib to your YAML front matter and use Pandoc citations ([@key]).
Inline citations render at 0.8em with a lighter color for visual distinction from body text.
Reference list (#refs div) uses rem-based sizing with automatic shrinking:



Reference count
Font size




1–5
0.6rem


6–10
0.5rem (auto-shrink)


11+
0.4rem (auto-shrink)



Auto-shrink uses CSS :has(.csl-entry:nth-child(n)) — no JavaScript needed.

title: CSS Class Reference
text:
Quick Examples

Dense content slide
## Full Regression Output {.small-slide}

- Lots of content here...


Section divider
# Methods {.section-slide}


Emphasis in text
The result is [statistically significant]{.alert} with
[p < 0.001]{.highlight}.


Font size in a div
::: {.small}
This entire block is smaller, including any code inside it.
:::


Cross-reference button
## Results

[[See Methods]{.button}](#methods-slide)

## Methods {#methods-slide}

title: Getting Started
text:
quarto add Data-Wise/dtslides
This installs both themes (Academic and UNM) under _extensions/. Check the directory into version control. Requires Quarto >= 1.6.0.

title: Getting Started
text:
quarto add Data-Wise/dtslides
This installs both themes (Academic and UNM) under _extensions/. Check the directory into version control. Requires Quarto >= 1.6.0.

title: Getting Started
text:
Updating
quarto update Data-Wise/dtslides
This replaces the extension files under _extensions/ while preserving your .qmd files and any custom SCSS overrides.

title: Getting Started
text:
Upgrading from unm-revealjs
If you previously used the unm-revealjs extension (v1.0.x):

Remove the old extension:
rm -rf _extensions/unm
Install the new extension:
quarto add Data-Wise/dtslides
Update your YAML front matter:
# Before
format:
  unm-revealjs:
    slide-number: c/t

# After
format:
  dtslides-unm-revealjs:
    slide-number: c/t

All CSS classes, callouts, and slide options work the same way — only the format string changed.

title: Getting Started
text:
Using the Themes

Academic theme
---
title: "My Presentation"
format:
  dtslides-revealjs:
    slide-number: c/t
---


UNM theme
---
title: "My Presentation"
format:
  dtslides-unm-revealjs:
    slide-number: c/t
---

title: Getting Started
Getting Started
dtslides Feature Showcase
text:
About This Showcase
This presentation demonstrates the capabilities of the dtslides extension for Quarto RevealJS.
It covers:

Markdown & Typography
Layouts & Columns
Code & Syntax Highlighting
Math & Equations
Custom Theme Classes
Interactive Elements

title: dtslides Feature Showcase
text:
Text Formatting
We support standard Markdown formatting:

Bold text for emphasis
Italic text for nuance
Strikethrough for deletions
Inline code for technical terms
Links to resources


“Blockquotes are useful for citing sources or highlighting key concepts.”

title: dtslides Feature Showcase
text:
Lists & Fragments
Lists can be revealed sequentially using fragments:


First item (appears first)




Second item (appears second)




Third item (appears last)

Nested item A
Nested item B

title: dtslides Feature Showcase
text:
Slide Sizes
This slide uses the .small-slide class.

Content is smaller (80% size).
Useful for slides with slightly more content.
Still maintains readability.

title: dtslides Feature Showcase
text:
Tiny Slide
This slide uses the .tiny-slide class (40% size).

This is useful for very dense information.
Reference lists.
Detailed code blocks that need to fit on one screen.
Appendix material.
Item 5
Item 6
Item 7
Item 8
Item 9
Item 10

title: dtslides Feature Showcase
text:
Multiple Columns


Left Column
This column takes up 50% of the slide width.

Point A
Point B


Right Column
This column also takes up 50%.

Point C
Point D

title: dtslides Feature Showcase
text:
Column Layouts with Images


Text & Context
You can place text on one side to explain a visual element.

Explanation 1
Explanation 2





Placeholder Image

title: dtslides Feature Showcase
text:
Tabsets

R CodePython CodeAnalysis


library(ggplot2)
ggplot(mtcars, aes(mpg, hp)) + geom_point()


import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
plt.scatter(mtcars["mpg"], mtcars["hp"])
plt.show()


Tabsets allow you to organize content without cluttering the slide. Great for switching between languages or results.

title: dtslides Feature Showcase
text:
R Code Execution
Standard R code blocks with output:

library(ggplot2)
ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg, color = factor(cyl))) +
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Motor Trend Car Road Tests")

title: dtslides Feature Showcase
text:
Side-by-Side Code & Output
Using output-location: column:


# Generate data
x <- rnorm(100)
y <- 2 * x + rnorm(100)

# Fit model
model <- lm(y ~ x)

# Plot
par(mar = c(4, 4, 1, 1))
plot(x, y, pch = 19, col = "steelblue")
abline(model, lwd = 2, col = "darkred")

title: dtslides Feature Showcase
text:
LaTeX Support
Mathematical equations are rendered beautifully using MathJax.
Inline math: \(E = mc^2\)
Display math:
\[
\frac{\partial \rho}{\partial t} + \nabla \cdot (\rho \mathbf{v}) = 0
\]
Aligned equations:
\[
\begin{align}
f(x) &= a x^2 + b x + c \\
f'(x) &= 2 a x + b
\end{align}
\]

title: dtslides Feature Showcase
text:
Custom Classes
The dtslides theme includes special utility classes:

Alert text for emphasis (.alert)
Custom Foreground (.fg)
Highlighted text (.highlight)
Note style (.note)
Warning style (.warning)

title: dtslides Feature Showcase
text:
Standard Callouts






Note


Note callouts are great for non-critical information.









Important


Important callouts highlight critical warnings.









Tip


Tip callouts suggest best practices.

title: dtslides Feature Showcase
text:
Theme-Specific Callouts
The theme provides custom semantic callouts:

Example: A worked problem or specific case study.


Question: A prompt for audience reflection or discussion.


Insight: A deeper observation or key takeaway.

title: dtslides Feature Showcase
text:
Summary
This template provides a robust foundation for academic and professional presentations.
Key features: 1. Clean, readable typography. 2. Flexible layout options. 3. Rich code and math support. 4. Customizable thematic elements.

title: dtslides Feature Showcase
text:
Thank You
Questions?
contact@email.com

title: Introduction to Statistical Methods
text:
Overview
This presentation demonstrates the academic theme — a clean, neutral design suitable for any institution.

Navy/slate color palette
No institutional branding
Same feature set as the UNM theme

title: Introduction to Statistical Methods
text:
Text Formatting
Standard Markdown formatting works seamlessly:

Bold text for emphasis
Italic text for nuance
Strikethrough for deletions
Inline code for technical terms like lm() or ggplot2
Links to resources


“All models are wrong, but some are useful.” — George Box

title: Introduction to Statistical Methods
text:
Lists & Fragments
Use ::: {.fragment} to reveal items one at a time:


State the null hypothesis \(H_0\)




Choose a significance level \(\alpha\)




Compute the test statistic




Compare to critical value or compute \(p\)-value

title: Introduction to Statistical Methods
text:
Incremental Lists
Add {.incremental} to auto-fragment every bullet:

Assumption checking
Model fitting
Diagnostics
Interpretation

.largest (1.20em)
.larger (1.50em)
.large (1.25em)
Normal text (1em)
.small (0.80em)
.smaller (0.64em)
.smallest (0.512em)


Code blocks scale too:

# .small code block
summary(lm(y ~ x))

title: Introduction to Statistical Methods
text:
Small Slide
Use {.small-slide} for slides with more content (80% font size).

Useful when you need to fit slightly more text
Keeps readability while increasing density
Great for summary or review slides

title: Introduction to Statistical Methods
text:
Tiny Slide
Use {.tiny-slide} for very dense information (40% font size).

Reference lists
Detailed code output
Appendix material
Supplementary tables
Method details
Full regression output
Assumption checks
Sensitivity analyses
Additional citations
Technical notes

title: Introduction to Statistical Methods
text:
Quote Slide

“The best thing about being a statistician is that you get to play in everyone’s backyard.”

— John Tukey

title: Introduction to Statistical Methods
text:
Scrollable Slide
Add {.scrollable} to the slide title for long content.

set.seed(42)
n <- 200
x1 <- rnorm(n)
x2 <- rnorm(n)
x3 <- rnorm(n)
y <- 3 + 2*x1 - 1.5*x2 + 0.8*x3 + rnorm(n)
fit <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2 + x3)
summary(fit)


Call:
lm(formula = y ~ x1 + x2 + x3)

Residuals:
     Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
-2.93441 -0.62144  0.03289  0.72861  2.25916 

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)  2.86990    0.06621   43.35   <2e-16 ***
x1           1.94150    0.06826   28.44   <2e-16 ***
x2          -1.49839    0.07029  -21.32   <2e-16 ***
x3           0.79215    0.06384   12.41   <2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 0.9344 on 196 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.8813,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.8795 
F-statistic: 485.3 on 3 and 196 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

confint(fit)

                 2.5 %     97.5 %
(Intercept)  2.7393263  3.0004766
x1           1.8068779  2.0761290
x2          -1.6370243 -1.3597633
x3           0.6662528  0.9180429

title: Introduction to Statistical Methods
text:
Two Columns


Left Column

Regression assumptions
Linearity
Normality of residuals
Homoscedasticity


Right Column

Diagnostic tools
Residual plots
Q-Q plots
Cook’s distance

title: Introduction to Statistical Methods
text:
Columns with Code & Output


The Model
We fit a simple linear regression:
\[\hat{y} = b_0 + b_1 x\]
where \(b_0\) and \(b_1\) are estimated via OLS.


set.seed(42)
x <- rnorm(50)
y <- 2 + 3*x + rnorm(50)
plot(x, y, pch = 19,
     col = "#4A6FA5")
abline(lm(y ~ x),
       col = "#1B365D", lwd = 2)

...

x <- rnorm(100)
y <- 2 * x + rnorm(100, sd = 0.5)
summary(lm(y ~ x))


Call:
lm(formula = y ~ x)

Residuals:

-0.94421 -0.25332  0.00612  0.27053  1.43120 

Coefficients:

(Intercept) -0.04418    0.04544  -0.972    0.333

Multiple R-squared:  0.9556,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.9552 
F-statistic:  2110 on 1 and 98 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

R Plot Output

library(ggplot2)

  geom_point(size = 3) +

title: Introduction to Statistical Methods
text:
Code with Filename
Use filename to label code blocks:



analysis.R

# Load and prepare data
library(dplyr)
data <- read.csv("experiment.csv") |>
  filter(!is.na(response)) |>
  mutate(group = factor(group))

# Fit ANOVA
model <- aov(response ~ group, data = data)
summary(model)
TukeyHSD(model)

title: Introduction to Statistical Methods
text:
LaTeX Support
Inline math: The sample mean is \(\bar{x} = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_i\).
Display math:
\[
f(x \mid \mu, \sigma^2) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^2}} \exp\left(-\frac{(x - \mu)^2}{2\sigma^2}\right)
\]
Aligned equations:
\[
\begin{align}
\hat{\beta} &= (X'X)^{-1}X'y \\
\text{Var}(\hat{\beta}) &= \sigma^2 (X'X)^{-1} \\
\hat{\sigma}^2 &= \frac{e'e}{n - p}
\end{align}
\]

title: Introduction to Statistical Methods
text:
Standard Quarto Callouts






Note


Note callouts are great for supplementary information.









Important


Important callouts highlight critical warnings.









Tip


Tip callouts suggest best practices and shortcuts.

title: Introduction to Statistical Methods
text:
Theme-Specific Callouts
Use divs ::: {.callout-type} for custom boxes:

Consider a study with \(n = 30\) subjects. The sample mean is \(\bar{x} = 5.2\) with \(s = 1.8\). A 95% CI for \(\mu\) is \((4.53, 5.87)\).


How does increasing the sample size affect the width of the confidence interval?


The CI width decreases at rate \(1/\sqrt{n}\), so quadrupling the sample size halves the interval width.

title: Introduction to Statistical Methods
text:
Centered Content
This slide uses {.center} to vertically center all content.
Perfect for title cards or key takeaways.
Key Finding: The treatment effect was statistically significant (\(p < .001\)).

title: Introduction to Statistical Methods
text:
Inline Citations
As Box (1976) famously noted, all models are wrong but some are useful.
The bootstrap method (Efron and Tibshirani 1993) provides a nonparametric approach to inference. Exploratory data analysis (Tukey 1977) is a crucial first step. Classical foundations include (Fisher 1925) and (Neyman and Pearson 1933).
Modern methods span Bayesian analysis (Gelman et al. 2013), random forests (Breiman 2001), regularization (Tibshirani 1996), causal inference (Pearl 2009; Rubin 1974), machine learning (Hastie, Tibshirani, and Friedman 2009), and survival analysis (Cox 1972).

title: Introduction to Statistical Methods
text:
References


Box, George E. P. 1976. “Science and Statistics.” Journal of the American Statistical Association 71 (356): 791–99.


Breiman, Leo. 2001. “Random Forests.” Machine Learning 45: 5–32.


Cox, David R. 1972. “Regression Models and Life-Tables.” Journal of the Royal Statistical Society B 34 (2): 187–220.


Efron, Bradley, and Robert J. Tibshirani. 1993. An Introduction to the Bootstrap. Chapman; Hall.


Fisher, Ronald A. 1925. “Statistical Methods for Research Workers.” Edinburgh: Oliver and Boyd.


Gelman, Andrew, John B. Carlin, Hal S. Stern, David B. Dunson, Aki Vehtari, and Donald B. Rubin. 2013. Bayesian Data Analysis. 3rd ed. Chapman; Hall/CRC.


Hastie, Trevor, Robert Tibshirani, and Jerome Friedman. 2009. The Elements of Statistical Learning. 2nd ed. Springer.


Neyman, Jerzy, and Egon S. Pearson. 1933. “On the Problem of the Most Efficient Tests of Statistical Hypotheses.” Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A 231: 289–337.


Pearl, Judea. 2009. “Causality: Models, Reasoning, and Inference.” Cambridge University Press.


Rubin, Donald B. 1974. “Estimating Causal Effects of Treatments in Randomized and Nonrandomized Studies.” Journal of Educational Psychology 66 (5): 688–701.


Tibshirani, Robert. 1996. “Regression Shrinkage and Selection via the Lasso.” Journal of the Royal Statistical Society B 58 (1): 267–88.


Tukey, John W. 1977. “Exploratory Data Analysis.” Reading, MA: Addison-Wesley.

title: dtslides UNM Theme
text:
Additional theme classes
Special classes for emphasis

.alert class for default emphasis, e.g. [important note]{.alert} ==> important note.
.fg class for custom color, e.g. important note.
.bg class for custom background, e.g. important note.
.highlight class for highlighting, e.g. important note.
.note class for notes, e.g. important note.
.warning class for warnings, e.g. warning note.

Cross-references

.button class provides a Beamer-like button, e.g.

[[Call-out Section]{.button}](#callout-sec) Call-out Section

title: dtslides UNM Theme
text:
Code blocks I
This is a regular code block in a slide:

# This is an R code block
x <- rnorm(100)
y <- 2 * x + rnorm(100)
summary(lm(y ~ x))


Call:
lm(formula = y ~ x)

Residuals:
     Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
-2.85358 -0.72693 -0.03036  0.73559  2.67368 

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept) -0.19465    0.10378  -1.876   0.0637 .  
x            1.99678    0.09593  20.814   <2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 1.037 on 98 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.8155,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.8136 
F-statistic: 433.2 on 1 and 98 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

title: dtslides UNM Theme
text:
Code blocks II
This is a regular code block with the cell option, output-location: column:


# This is an R code block
x <- rnorm(100)
y <- 2 * x + rnorm(100)
summary(lm(y ~ x))



Call:
lm(formula = y ~ x)

Residuals:
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-2.0423 -0.6618 -0.1700  0.5641  2.8984 

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)  0.07741    0.09200   0.841    0.402    
x            1.99232    0.10044  19.837   <2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 0.918 on 98 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.8006,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.7986

title: dtslides UNM Theme
text:
Code blocks III
This is a code slide with the class {.small-slide}, which is useful for code-heavy slides.

N <- 12 # Number of experimental units, Step 1
# Define experimental units and treatments
experimental_units <- 1:N ## 10 experimental units
treatments <- c("A", "B", "C") ## 3 treatments, Step 2

# Repeat treatments to match the number of units. The code covers both balanced and unbalanced designs.
treatments <- rep(treatments, length.out = N) ## Step 3

# For a balanced design, we can also use:
# treatments <- rep(treatments, each = N/length(treatments))

# Shuffle (randomize) treatments randomly to assign to units, Step 4
set.seed(123) ## For reproducibility
randomized_treatments <- sample(treatments)

# Create a data frame with randomized assignments
randomization_crd <- data.frame(Unit = experimental_units, Treatment = randomized_treatments) ## Step 5
print(randomization_crd)

   Unit Treatment
1     1         C
2     2         C
3     3         A
4     4         B
5     5         C
6     6         B
7     7         B
8     8         A
9     9         C
10   10         B
11   11         A
12   12         A

title: dtslides
text: Two polished reveal.js presentation themes with shared layout architecture — slide types, emphasis classes, callouts, font utilities, styled tables, and citation support from a single install.

title: dtslides
text:
Themes



  
    
    
    
    
    
    
  
  
    Academic
    Clean, institution-neutral design. Navy/slate palette suited for any department or conference.
  

format:
  dtslides-revealjs:
    slide-number: c/t
Live Demo


  
    
    
    
    
    
    
  
  
    UNM
    University of New Mexico branding. Cherry/turquoise palette with official logos.
  

format:
  dtslides-unm-revealjs:
    slide-number: c/t
Live Demo Extended Demo

title: dtslides
text:
Install
quarto add Data-Wise/dtslides
Installs both themes under _extensions/. Requires Quarto >= 1.6.0. See Getting Started for usage and customization.

title: dtslides
text:
Features

  
    Slide Types
    .small-slide .tiny-slide .quote-slide .image-slide .section-slide .slide-code .scrollable
  
  
    Emphasis & Highlighting
    .alert .fg .bg .highlight .note .warning — inline spans for drawing attention to key content.
  
  
    Custom Callouts
    .callout-example .callout-question .callout-insight plus all standard Quarto callouts, styled to match each theme.
  
  
    Font Sizing
    .largest through .smallest — apply to slides or divs. Code blocks inside scale proportionally.
  
  
    Layout Utilities
    Text alignment (.left .center .right), vertical positioning (.v-center .v-top .v-bottom), buttons, badges.
  
  
    Citations & References
    Pandoc citeproc citations styled at 0.8em. Reference lists auto-shrink at 6+ and 11+ entries — no JavaScript needed.
  

See the full CSS Class Reference for usage examples.

title: dtslides
